title: Two pipes can fill a tank in 12 minutes and 20 minutes respectively. Both pipes are opened together and after some time the first pipe is closed and the tank is full in totally 10 minutes. For how many minutes was first pipe open? - Quora

response.answer_text: 1st pipe can fill tank in 12 minutes So in 1 minute it fills 1/12 of the tank Similarly second pipe fills 1/20 of the tank in 1 minute Second pipe fills 10/20 in 10 minutes. i.e 1/2 tank So both pipes were open to fill 1/2 tank Both pipes in 1 minute fill 1/12+1/20 = 32/240= 2/15 of the tank So both will fill tank in 15/2 = 7.5 minutes So 1/2 tank will take 3.75 minutes First pipe open for 3.75 minutes ANSWER CHECK 1st pipe 3.75 minutes = 3.75/12 = 0.3125 second pipe 13.75 minutes = 13.75/20 = 0.6875 ADD = 1.00 full tank

Let the first pipe be P1 & the time be T1 Let the second pipe be P2 & the time be T2 Here the common for both of the pipe is filling the tank full of water which is considered as volume as 100% The time taken by both of the pipes are variable & diameter of the pipe depends on time, lesser the time more the diameter of pipe or vice versa. Here, dimensions of tank, diameter of pipes, velocity of water, viscosity etc are not taken into account it's logic depends upon time & imaginable diameter of pipes. P1 x T1 = 100 P1 x 12 = 100 P1 = 8.333 eq.(1) This is the percentage of water filled in tank by pipe P1 at 1 min. P2 x T2 = 100 P2 x 20 = 100 P2 = 5 eq.(2) This is the percentage of water filled in tank by pipe P2 at 1 min. Both of pipes P1 & P2 fill the tank for some time (T3) & pipe P2 alone fill the tank for totally 10 min (T4), thus filling the tank by 100% (P1+P2) T3 + (P2 x T4) = 100 (8.333+5) T3 + (5 x (10-T3)) = 100 T3 = 6 min Hence, the first pipe P1 opens for 6 min If both of the pipes combined together, (P1+P2) T5 = 100 (8.333+5) T5 = 100 T5 = 7.5 min This both pipes combined will fill the tank in 7.5 min (or) 7 min 30 sec.
